content.caption: Endless Runner Game Template with Motion Matching (v1.4)

content.value: This document serves as a comprehensive guide to the Infinite Runner Template, which has been integrated with Motion Matching. The template provides a robust framework for creating endless runner games in Unreal Engine, featuring dynamic obstacle generation, character selection, customization, and a power-ups system.

value: Showcase Videos:
<ul>
• Version 1.3
• Version 1.2
• Version 1.1
• Version 1.0

content.value: Support: For questions or assistance, please leave a comment on the product page or join the Discord server. Please consider rating and reviewing the asset if it proves useful.

Track the progress as the project upgrades.
  • Green items are live,
  • Blue are currently being worked on
  • and Yellow are planned for future releases.

features: Dynamic Obstacles (can be slid under or climbed)
Added Toggle Control for various features
Added Theme based Spawn Zone System (Sequential & Random)
Added Stability Controls for First Person Camera
Added Roll on Forced Jump Ends
Added Emoting Mechanic on Character Selection Screen
Parkour can now be disabled on certain obstacles
Added New Demo Maps - RunnerMap(Default), DayMap and NightMap
Updated Character Selection System to Version 1.2
Updated Character Customization System to Version 1.1
Updated Widgets Management System to Version 1.1
Solved the issue of disappearing mouse cursor on widget screens.

content.value: Motion Matching: This project uses the customized setup from the GameAnimationSampleProject (GASP) for Motion Matching. No new motion matching setup was specifically created for this project.

The default setup has been modified to improve gameplay fluidity. But you will need to add  specific animations to improve the results. The existing GASP animations have been repurposed for various actions.

Required Plugins:
  • Animation: AnimationWarping, MotionWarping, AnimationLocomotionLibrary, PoseSearch, Chooser, RigLogic, LiveLink, LiveLinkControlRig.
  • Tools: ModelingToolsEditorMode, HairStrands, Mover, NetworkPrediction.
Collision: A new object trace channel called "Collectibles" has been added (Default Behavior: Ignore).
GameModeVariant: A new game mode variant of infinite runner - Vector, has been added to the project.

• No Save Data: The project does not use a GameInstanceClass. Data is not saved between levels or game replays.
  • Customization Reset: Any customization items attached to a character are lost if the character is changed.
The project is intended to be used as a base starting project.
UI: Record Label and Value in the top-right corner of screen is partially implemented. As long as you do not change levels, the value of record will be updated and read from gameMode.

Migration Guide: The system is heavily interface-driven. Though modular, this project is not intended for migration into existing projects. However, you can easily download and integrate Character Selection System V1.2, Character Customization System V1.1, and Widgets Management System V1.1 selectively from FAB.
Character Selection System V1.2, Character Customization System V1.1, Widgets Management System V1.1 have been improved to align them with the project.

There are 2 different infinite runner game variants -
  • Normal (Runner) Mode: 3 Lane FP/TP Runner
  • Vector Mode: Single Lane Sidescroller Infinite Runner

value: • 5 Preset powerUps - SuperJump, Invincibility, Magnet, DoubleCoins, ScoreBooster.
• PowerUps attachments for visual indication.
• Improved PowerUp management logic.
• Fixed bugs related to invincibility.
• PowerUp widgets are now spawned and displayed on screen.
• PowerUps are reset when an already equipped powerUp is equipped again.
• Character Animations can now be modified when powerUps are equipped based on three categories - FullBody, LeftBody and RightBody.

• New Character Animation Modification System that can be easily extended to micro-control creation and modification of existing animations for unique character animations by blending each body part with an unique animation during an action.
• The traversal animations chooser has been modified to include only run-related traversal animations.
• A copy of original traversal animation chooser is also present for reference to add new animations.
• The PowerUps System also uses a similar system to blend modifier animations.
• Improved blending, transitions, and added a settings toggle in the main menu.
• Camera animations on character customization screen based on the customization category.
• Stability Control with First Person Camera.
• Play LevelSequences in background of the widget screens.
• Enhanced Emote System to further enhance widget screen interactions.
• SpawnZones based platform spawning (Sequential and Random).
• Modified obstacle spawning logic on static platforms.
• Modified Random platforms spawning logic.
<ul>
• Environment Creation Tools have been included in the project.
• Support for both static and animatable skeletal meshes.
• Control over how far from the player, the skeletal mesh animation plays.
• Ability to create environments separately and attach them to platforms.
• More toggle controls over gameplay mechanics,

• Mesh attachements when PowerUps are equipped,
  • Spawned PowerUps Indicator,
• Roll mechanic on forced jump ends.
• Control movement sensitivity in First Person Camera.
• Obstacles and Collectibles Spawning logic updated.
• Reorganized blueprints and commented code for better readability.
• Fixed some collision issues.
• Solved the issue of disappearing mouse cursor on widget screens.
• Space: Jump / Air-Parkour
• C: Slide
• A: Move Left
• D: Move Right
• C (While Jumping) Or R: Roll
<ul>
• The main character class is - CBP_SandboxCharacter.
• The main anim blueprint class is - ABP_SandboxCharacter.
• The RetargetedCharacters use GenericRetargeter for driving animations off of main character class.

content.value: The logic for various actions is separated into different graphs.

value: • In the EventGraph, add Event_BeginPlay node.
• Right-click on the node and select AddCallToParent node.
• Now right-click and search for - Set PlayerSkeletalMesh node.
• Bring in your retargeted character skeletal mesh and connect it to PlayerSkeletalMesh node.
The animation blueprint is modified for custom animation modification and stabilizing camera movement.
• P_CameraBlended: Outputs poses blended for ThirdPerson/FirstPerson states. It is the final blended state.
• P_PowerBlended: Outputs animation data after modification/layering from other animations on targeted bones according to equipped higher priority powerUp.
• P_AnimModified: Outputs animation data after modification/layering from other animations on targeted bones.
• P_MotionMatched: Outputs motion matched animation data.

• Logic: When a traversal action occurs or UseCustomAnimationData is false, modification stops. You can plug any animation or custom processed pose at the place of ‘M_Neutral_Stand_Idle_Loop’ for better camera control.

content.value:
Enable UseCustomAnimationData to modify animations for specific actions (e.g., Running, Jumping) .
Define a ModifierAnimation, a BlendValue (0.0–1.0), and a list of BoneToAffect (from E_BonesToModify).Current categories: UpperBody, LeftArm, RightArm, LeftThigh, RightThigh.

value: <ul>
• Responsible for managing platform spawn data based on the selected game mode variant.
• AddWidgetToScreen interface call is executed by the game mode which in turn asks the HUD_RunnerManager to add the requested widget.
• Also manages game variant based CurvedWorldShading.
• Dummy implementation for saving player run stats.

• Lifecycle of a platform:
    • AddFloor: Spawns initial tiles.
    • ExtendFloor: Spawns new tile when player overlaps detector.
    • DeleteFloor: Removes oldest tile to maintain performance.
<ul>
• TimeToDeleteEarliestFloor: Determines the duration (in seconds) after which the platform will be removed/destroyed if the player has overlapped with the respective detector box.
• VectorLane: The lane position where the platforms must be spawned for vector game variant.
• NormalLaneData: The lane positions where the platforms must be spawned and character movement is allowed for normal runner game variant.
• NormalRunnerZones: The data asset that contains the configuration for spawn zones that can be spawned for normal runner game variant.
• VectorRunnerZones: The data asset that contains the configuration for spawn zones that can be spawned for vector game variant.
• WidgetDataBase:The data asset that contains the configurations for adding widgets to screen on demand.
You can change how many floors to at add the start of the game & every time extension is requested by changing StartWithFloors & ExtensionCount in BPC_EndlessAttributesComponent respectively.
• Make sure the player controller class is set to - PC_RunnerController.
• Make sure the HUD class is set to - HUD_RunnerManager.
• Make sure the default pawn class is set to first character in your character selection list data asset.
• If the timer for deleting a floor expires, but the character is still on the floor, then it will fall into oblivion.
<ul>
• Child Class of PC_Sandbox.
• Responsible for managing player character data.
• Deactivation of fetching characters in either directions on the character selection screen is also managed here.
• Also determines whether the character selection list will be BidirectionalCircular or Linear.
• Actual logic of fetching character in either direction is managed in the parent class.
<ul>
• CharacterData: The data asset that contains the list of available characters.
• CircularList: Determines whether or not the character selection list is Bidirectionally Circular or Linear.
• DebugButtonStates: Prints when fetch Next or Previous character becomes passive(deactivated).
Make sure the first character in your character selection list is the same character assigned as default pawn in the game mode.
<ul>
• Responsible for management of on-screen widgets.
• Based on widgets configuration, correspondiing level sequences are played in the background of the widget screens.
• It is called by the game mode internally when any widget is requested.
• It is based on Widgets Management System V1.1.
• The visibility of mouse cursor is also managed here depending on whether or not the current widget state is "Gameplay HUD".
There are no configurable properties in this class. Widgets data asset for adding/removing widgets is fetched from the game mode.
Make sure your character has BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributes otherwise widgets system will not work correctly.
Do not modify CachedWidget directly/indirectly inside or from outside. It is categorized under Privates but not marked private to allow instant access to game mode when required.
<ul>
• Create a new widget blueprint of your choice.
• Go to MM_Runner > Components > Widgets > Enumeration and open E_WidgetScreen.
• Add a new enumeration value and rename it to your desired category.
• Click Save.
• Now go to MM_Runner > Components > Widgets > DataAsset and open DA_PDA_WidgetData.
• Add a new element by clicking the plus icon.

content.value: You can also create a new camera rig and assign it in the CameraDirector_SandboxCharacter's "WidgetController" code block on switch enum to further elevate your game :)

value: <ul>
• WidgetScreen: Select your widget category.
• WidgetElement: Assign the widget blueprint relative to this category.
• PlayLevelSequence: This toggle determines whether or not level sequences will be played in the background of this widget.
• LevelSequences: Add the level sequences that can be played in this array. Only required if PlayLevelSequence boolean is True.
<ul>
• PlayableSequence: Assign a valid level sequence.
• PlayRate: Adjust the play rate of this level sequence.
• Transform: By default, all level sequences are played relative to the player. Use these transform values to adjust the sequence relative to player.

content.value: These widget elements have been used to create the existing widget blueprints. The widgets management is not tied to them and you can use your own custom widgets too.

value: <ul>
• Name: Assign the name of the button.
• Typeface: The text can be either Regular or Bold.
• FontFamily: Change the font family of this button text.
• FontSize: Set the font size.
• SkewText: Skew the text using float value.
• Spacing: Adjust the letter spacing.
• Scale: Change the render scale of the text in X and Y directions.
• ColorData: Assign the colors of this button during various events - normal, hovered, clicked, passive, etc;
• MonoSpacing: Toggle for whether or not to use monospacing for this button text.
• MonoSpacingWidth: Adjust the monospacing width.
• ShadowColor: Customize the shadow color for this button text.
• ShadowOffset: Adjust the shadow offset.
• Status: Whether or not the button the active on start. Depending on the status, the assigned colors will appear.
• WarpText: Whether or not to adjust the text within the bounds of the button.
• BackgroundBlur: Adjust the strength of the background blur behind the text.
<ul>
• SetButtonStatus: This function is used to toggle between the active and passive states.
• ButtonIsClicked: This event dispatcher is used to simulate button click action.
These properties are used in some other widget elements. It is possible that not all of these properties are used for any element and you may have to manually customize it.

content.value: This is simply an empty element that occupies space. I created this because I was finding it hard to keep track of many horizontal and vertical boxes in the widgets. It serves no actual purpose related to gameplay.

value: <ul>
• SlotWidgetElement: Leave this empty.
• Size: Change if you want the empty to occupy all the space or part of it.
• Padding: Adjust the padding of this empty in the 4 directions.
• Horizontal & Vertical Alignment: Adjust the empty's alignment.

content.value: This is for on-screen text that never changes.
• It uses all the same text properties as to E_Button element.
This is for on-screen text that changes based on player actions.

value: • It uses all the same text properties as to E_Button element.
• It uses SetNewText function to change on-screen text.

content.value: This is an image based widget element. Wherever an image was needed, this was used.

value: • It uses SetNewImage function to change on-screen image. Takes a Texture2D format file as input.

content.value:
This is an element where you can plug in 2 different widget elements in the key value pair form.
e.g. Score(E_FixedText) & ScoreVal(E_VariableText).

value: • It uses SetKeyElement function to change on-screen image. Takes a Texture2D format file as input.

content.value:
This is an element where you can plug in 2 different text data in the key value pair form.
e.g. Score(Key) & ScoreVal(Value).

value: • It uses SetPairKeyText & SetPairValueText function to change key-value data independently during runtime.
• It uses SetPairKeyText & SetPairValueText function to change key-value data independently during runtime.

content.value: This is an image based element with text at the bottom. It is used for active powerUp indicators.

value: • It uses SetPairKeyText & SetPairValueText function to change key-value data independently during runtime.
• It uses SetPairKeyText & SetPairValueText function to change key-value data independently during runtime.
<ul>
• Responsible for management of camera screens.
• Directly tied to variables from current character's BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributes.
• Existing camera rigs can be modified or new ones can be created based on your familiarity with the Camera Rigs.
• Lot of camera rigs are already present in the project for many different actions and widget screens.
• The camera rig evaluation logic has been modularized into many different custom events for better readability.
There are no configurable properties in this class. Camera rigs are managed on the basis of variables present in BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributes directly fetched from current player pawn.
Make sure your character has BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributes otherwise camera system will not work correctly.

content.value: This template has been built with modular architecture in mind. Everything is organized in its own isolated space. Interfaces and player pawn reference serve as the communication channels :)
This component manages critical character and gameplay data.

value: <ul>

• SpeedUpdateRate: The rate at which player speed is updated.
    If set to say 1000, then at every 1000 added to score, the speed will be increased.
• MaxWalkSpeed: The maximum walk speed the player can attain after multiple speed updates.
• WalkSpeedUpdateRate: The factor by which the character's walking speed is increased.
<ul>
• ScoreUpdateTimer: The interval at which score is updated on screen.
• MinScoreIncrease: The minimum value that can be added to score at any instant.
• MaxScoreIncrease: The maximum value that can be added to score at any instant.
<ul>
• StartWithFloors: The number of platforms which will be spawned for the first time when the player starts running.
• DeathTracerRadius: The radius of the collision sphere for checking potential collisions.
• DeathTracerLoopTimer: The timer duration in seconds at which death sphere will check for collision.
• ForwardTraceDistance: The distance from the player till which the sphere checks for collision.
• DeathMontages: An array of animation montages any of which is randomly played on death screen if RagdollOnDeath is set to False.
<ul>
• DrawDebugDeathTracer: Useful for drawing collision sphere.
• DebugEmoteSequenceIndex: This prints which emote sequence index is currently playing on the character.
• DebugEmoteAnimMontage: This prints the name of the emote montage currently playing on the character.
<ul>
• AllowEmotes: Determines whether or not the character can emote at all.
• Wait Time: It is the amount of wait before the player starts to emote on any screen.
• Blend Out Time: Time taken to abruptly stop an emote.
• Min and Max Delays: A random time between these is used to blend out an emote abruptly when there is an another emote sequence to play.
• Emote Data: Data asset containing emoting sequences per widget screen.
<ul>
• Attributes (Title/Strength/Weakness): Decor data for displaying on CharacterSelection & CharacterCustomization screens.
• ToggleInBetweenLanes: Useful if you want the character to be able to toggle lanes in the midst of previous lane change action.
• SideWayMovementScale: This is usef to drive the intensity of sideways leaning animation when changing lanes.
• DriveLeaningAnimations: This toggle is used to determine whether or not to drive leaning animations at all.
• PlayRagdollOnDeath: This enables the character body to be able to ragdoll on colliding with the obstacles. If false, then any random valid animation montage from the DeathMontages array is played.
• PlayReactionOnBump: This toggle is supposed to determine whether the character should play hit reaction on bumping any obstacle sideways. It is yet to be implemented correctly.
• RespawnKeyCount: This is useful if you want the character to have few keys at the start of the game already.
<ul>
• CameraSystem: Determines the primary camera type for the player.
• FP DynamicTranslationOffset: Useful for adjusting the camera location relative to character's head in FirstPerson mode.
• FP DynamicRotationOffset: Useful for adjusting the camera rotation relative to character's head in FirstPerson mode.
• High&Low SensitivityHeadBlend: Respectively determine the extent of head wobbling of running and other animations on the player character's head to stabilize the motion during various actions.
• SlowDownTime: To further control the head wobbling, you can adjust the time dilation on the player character.
<ul>
• RespawnKeyCount variable should not be directly updated. Use the functions Get_RespawnKeyCount, IncrementRespawnKeys & DecrementRespawnKeys.
• It is recommended not to crank up the number of floors to spawn at the start of the game very high.
• Some of the toggles and features have been removed from previous version because they were bugging the game. They will likely be added later with improved & isolated logic.
Emote Data Asset: This is a map of emote data with respect to a widget screen.
<ul>
• Abort Previous: This aborts the emote montage abruptly and starts a fresh sequence of emote montages available for a widget screen.
• If the previous emote sequence is not aborted, then the emote sequence related to previous widget screen is completed first and then the new emote sequence is used.
• AnimationMontages: Contains the montage sequences.
• SequenceStart: Contains the montage that is played for starting the sequence.
• SequenceEnd: Mostly used as transition from sequence to another.

• PlaySequentially: Whether or not to play all the montages in a sequential order. If not then any number of montages are selected and played for some time. When one sequence is complete, then another sequence from AnimationMontages array is searched and selected for playing if available.
You can define more than one montage sequence like –
• Standing up -> Greeting the player -> Sitting down
• Taking out phone -> Using it -> Putting it down

Note that any montage needs time to start and end. If the widget screens are switched a lot, the player character may glitch when playing montages becaues every widget screen on re-initializes the emote system.

content.value: The character data is fetched frome _DA_PDA_CharacterSelectionData. In this project, all characters must inherit CBP_SandboxCharacter to preserve running logic.

value: • Right Click on CBP_SandboxCharacter -> Create Child Class.
• In the event graph, plug the skeletal mesh component into PlayerSkeletonMesh.
• Create a new character data asset ( or duplicate existing) and fill the respective data.
• Name: Name of the character used for decorative purposes on the character selection screen.
• Class: Assign the class of newly created child character blueprint.
• Description: Fill in the lore details, background, or quick history of the character.
• Icon: Assign an icon to your character displayed on the top-left of the screen.
• CustomizationData: Assign the customization data for your character. For more info, check out the Character Customization Section.
• UseCustomAnimationData: This toggle determines whether or not character animations will be modified by the character animation modification system.
• CustomAnimationData: This is a map that contains action based animation modification data.
• Add the new DA to _DA_PDA_CharacterSelectionData.

content.value: You can add/rename categories by modifying the enumeration E_AttachmentPoints in MM_Runner > Components > Customization > Enumeration.

Customization data is fetched from the current character's data asset (DA_PDA_CD_xyz) which contains per-character selection and customization data. In this project, all characters must inherit CBP_SandboxCharacter to preserve running logic.

value: <ul>
• If you have setup your character class the right way then continue else refer to previous section for more info on Adding New Characters.
• Open your character's skeletal mesh.
• Setup sockets on your character skeleton.
• If you're using skeletal meshes such as clothing items, make sure they are rigged to the same character skeleton and properly weighted.

content.value: You can consider checking out how to set up sockets on your character's skeletal mesh on Youtube.

value: <ul>
• Go inside Components > Customization > DA folder and duplicate any existing data asset. Name it DA_PDA_CCD_yourCharacter.
• Open the data asset and click on the trash icon to empty the AttachmentData.
• Click the plus icon to add a new element in the map.
• The default value will be none. Click on it and select your desired category - Face, Torso, Legs or Shoes.
• Expand the section and click on plus icon to add items in that category.
• Always keep the first item in any category empty. This indicates the no attachments state for the character during the customization process.
<li>In the next item, fill the appropriate data -
<ul>
• isSkeletalMesh: Determines if or not the item to be attached to the character is a skeletal mesh or a static mesh.
• SkeletalMesh: If this item is a skeletal mesh, i.e. isSkeletalMesh is set to true, then select your desired mesh.
• AnimBPSkeletalMesh: If this skeletal mesh has its own animation blueprint, then select it here or leave it empty.
• UseMasterPose: Set this to true if you want this item to follow and character's animation data like clothing assets, else leave it false.
• StaticMesh: Select your static mesh asset if this item is not a skeletal mesh.

• AttachmentCategory: Select the category of this item. This category should be carefully set. The category of the map is used by the widget screen but the inside category is used by the player character.
• SocketName: The socket to which this item will be attached. If UseMasterPose is set to true, then leave it None.
• ItemDescription: This field can be used to write about the item's lore, defining features or properties.
<ul>
• CollectionRadius: Radius of the sphere tracer that works independently from death tracer.
• ForwardCollectionTraceDistance: Forward offset/end point of the sphere trace slightly ahead of the player.
• DrawDebugType: Useful for debugging collection tracer sphere.
• CollectionTimer: Timer looping value for collection tracer.
• CollectibleDisappearanceFX: Plays when any collectible is collected by the player.
• CollectiblePickUpSFX: SoundFX that plays when character collects the collectible.
• The below set of properties are used for spawning collectibles on platform.
• Collectibles are Instanced Static Meshes (ISMs) and do not currently animate towards the player.
<ul>
• CollectibleMesh: Static Mesh to spawn via Instanced Static Mesh Component.
• CollectibleCollisionType: This must be Collectibles only unless you wish to use a new object type for further extension. Other types are prone to interfere with other gameplay behaviors.
• LaneIdx: This controls on which lane collectibles are spawned depending on lane data fetched from game mode.
• No.OfCollectibles: This determines the number of instances to spawn over the obstacles.
• RowLocation: This is for adjusting the the collectibles in a lane.
• Scale: This changes the size of obstacles.
• CorrectiveZRotation: This is for changing the default rotation of the collectibles if they aren’t facing the desired direction on Z axis.
• GapBetweenInstances: This controls how far apart the collectibles instances will be from one another.
<ul>
• FlatDistance: Distance from the camera that is not curved.
• BaseDistance: Distance to curve.
• CurveExp: The rate/power of curve.
• CurveBool: Enables/Disables curved world shading.
• DirectionVector: Each component represents a respective XYZ direction. Alpha plays no role.
<ul>
• CheckCollisionDuringParkour: This is the duration of new death sphere tracer timer that is activated during parkour actions.
• CollisionTraceDebug: Useful for debugging purposes.
• Rolling & Sliding -
• SafeStop: Useful for avoiding collision during parkour action by calculating a safe stopping distance from any obstacle and giving players some time to change their strategy.
• ObstacleOffset Min&Max: The minimum and maximum distance from the obstacle at which the player should come to a stop safely.
• DrawDebugType: Useful for drawing the safe stop tracer for debugging purposes.
• OffsetTraceDistanceCover: This is the distance ahead of the player to start trace from.
• DistanceCover: This is the distance covered during any parkour action.
• WarpTargetName: Sliding action uses - Slide and Rolling action uses - Roll as warp target name.
• Montages: A random montage from the given array is played during the action.
<ul>
• The standard death tracer is turned off during parkour actions and a separate new collision tracer is initialized to allow selective collision behaviour during parkour.
• It is recommended to setup your parkour montages correctly by taking reference of the closest parkour action montage already present in the project.

• The rolling animation used here is clipped from jump landing roll montages. Due to its short length, the state switch from rolling to running has been delayed by a second in BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributesComponent.
<ul>
• Use this notify on parkour montages like Sliding, Rolling where when the player is in FirstPerson mode, camera stabilization mechanics do not interfere with the montage.
• See sliding and rolling montages present in the project for more details.

content.value: This is a blueprint that can spawn static and skeletal meshes and blueprint actors based on specified spawn rules with randomization options.
Overview of Environment Creation Tool Blueprint

value: Properties Configuration:
<ul>
• AutoUpdatePropsData: This can be used if you do not want to update the blueprint after every minor update.
• ShowFloor: This can be used to hide the default floor included with the environment. Hiding also turns off its collision properties and vice versa.
• FloorScaleVec: This can be used to scale the default floor in any of the directions.
• StaticPropsData: This is used to populate the environment with static meshes. Instanced Static Meshes are used for optimization purposes.
• SkeletalPropsData: This is used to populate the environment with skeletal meshes. This does not supports instancing, as a result, only one component can be spawned per array element.
• BPPropsData: This is used to populate the environment with blueprint actors. Though this does not supports instancing, you can still array these props.
<ul>
• Transform: This is used the as the base transform of the ISM component which will then spawn static meshes relative to it.
• StaticMeshAsset: This array contains the static mesh assets any of which can be used at a given moment.
• RandomAsset: This boolean toggles whether or not to use a random static mesh from the array.
• AssetIdx: If RandomAsset is false, then element at this index will be used. In case, this is an invalid index, then random static mesh will be used.
• Count: This determines the number of instances of the mesh in X, Y and Z directions respectively. Total number of instances spawned will be equal to the product these three values.
• Offset: This is used to add uniform gap between the instances in X, Y and Z directions respectively.
• InstanceTransform: This is useful for modifying the transforms of any instance.
• RemoveInstances: This is used for removing some of the instances of the static mesh.
• RandomDeletionCount: Based on this count, some of the instances will be deleted.
• RandomSeed: This boolean determines whether or not to use random seed for randomizing spawned instances.
• SeedValue: If RandomSeed is false, then the instances are transformed based on this seed value.
• TransformationMin & MaxRanges: This determines the maxium and minium extent of random transforms of the spawned instances.
• MaterialData: This is useful for randomizing the materials of the static meshes based on material indices.
• CollisionEnabled: This is useful if you want the player to collide with these instances.
<ul>
• Transform: This is used the as the base transform of the ISM component which will then spawn static meshes relative to it.
• SkeletalMeshAsset: This array contains the skeletal mesh assets any of which can be used at a given moment.
• RandomAsset: This boolean toggles whether or not to use a random static mesh from the array.
• AssetIdx: If RandomAsset is false, then element at this index will be used. In case, this is an invalid index, then random static mesh will be used.
• isAnimated: This determines whether or not to animate the skeletal mesh when player is around.
• MaterialData: This is useful for randomizing the materials of the mesh based on material indices.
• Animations: List of animations from which any one can be looped repeatedly.
• RandomSeed: This boolean determines whether or not to use random seed for randomizing data for this skeletal mesh asset.
• SeedValue: If RandomSeed is false, then the randomizations occur based on this seed value.
• TransformationMin & MaxRanges: This determines the maxium and minium extent of random transforms of the spawned instances.
• CollisionEnabled: This is useful if you want the player to collide with this mesh.
<ul>
• UseDefaultTransform: Toggle this if you wish to keep the base transforms of the original BP otherwise, it may be scaled relative to environment BP default scene root.
• Transform: This is used the as the base transform of the ISM component which will then spawn static meshes relative to it.

• BPAsset: This array contains the BP assets any of which can be used at a given moment. These are of type BP_DecorData but you can change it if you have other assets, otherwise create a child class of BP_DecorData and implement your custom BP logic.
• RandomAsset: This boolean toggles whether or not to use a random static mesh from the array.
• AssetIdx: If RandomAsset is false, then element at this index will be used. In case, this is an invalid index, then random static mesh will be used.
• Count: This determines the number of instances of the mesh in X, Y and Z directions respectively. Total number of instances spawned will be equal to the product these three values.
• Offset: This is used to add uniform gap between the instances in X, Y and Z directions respectively.
• InstanceTransform: This is useful for modifying the transforms of any instance.
• RemoveInstances: This is used for removing some of the instances of the static mesh.
• RandomSeed: This boolean determines whether or not to use random seed for randomizing spawned instances.
• SeedValue: If RandomSeed is false, then the instances are transformed based on this seed value.
• TransformationMin & MaxRanges: This determines the maxium and minium extent of random transforms of the spawned instances.
<ul>
• These are custom blueprints that contain custom logic/assets etc;
• These are spawned in the environment for increasing immersion.
<i> e.g. flickering lights, randomized street sign spawner, etc;
<ul>
• This component handles duration and effects of the equipped powerUps.
• Execution logic for any powerUp depends on its category, present in its respective EventGraph.
• Version 1.4 introduces resetting powerUps. When one powerUp that is equipped already is equipped again, then the previous one is instantly terminated and new one is started.
<ul>
• You can create one or more different powerUps by adding/modifying E_PowerType present in MM_Runner > Components > PowerUps > Enumeration folder.
<li>Based on the powerUpType, any powerUp will be implemented.

e.g. Even if Invincibility data asset changes the variables related to Score, Counter or Jump powerUps, none of those variables will affect the gameplay if the powerUp category is marked as Invincibility..
<ul>
<li>There are over 5+ powerUp presets already present in the project -
<ul>
• DA_DoubleCoins: Multiplies the value of every collectible by a factor of 2.
• DA_Invincibility: Allows the player to phase through obstacles. Any obstacle the player collides with is also destroyed(visibility turned off).
• DA_Magnet: Increases the collection radius of collectibles.
• DA_Regular: It is nothing but an empty powerUp. It is intended for duplication and modification to create a new powerUp.

• DA_ScoreMultiplier: Not exactly a multiplier but changes the range of values that are added to the score every frame(according to ScoreUpdateTimer set in player's BPC_EndlessRunnerAttributesComponent.

• DA_SuperJump: Current configuration allows the player to do superJump for a fixed duration. It also has many different jump configurations available say - manual one time jumper, jump pad, auto jumper, etc; by mixing-matching jumpType and jumpFreq categories.
<ul>
• Lowering the perks in these data assets will negatively impact the player performance like - slow score increase, unable to collect collectibles, etc;
• These negative powerUps can serve as another type of obstacles that the player should avoid.
<ul>
• PowerType: Assign a unique category of powerUp.
• PowerUpName: Assign a name to the powerUp.
• Priority: Only used for layering animation data on the player character.
• Duration: The duration for which this powerUp will remain active.
• DescriptionData: Write a description, for decoration only (will be used on store page when implemented).
• Icon: PowerUp icon that will be displayed on widgets.
• PickUpFX: The niagara FX that plays when the player picks this powerUp.
• PickUpSound: The SFX that plays when this powerUp is equipped.
• CharacterFX: The niagara FX that will be attached to the player for the duration of this powerUp.
• PickUpColor: Assign a color for uniquely identifying any powerUp from a distance.
• AttachementData: Based on the same logic as of CHaracterCustomizationSystem, useful adding character gear for powerUp visibility.
<ul>
• isSkeletalMesh: Determines whether to attach a new static or skeletal mesh component to the player character.
• UseMasterPose: Set it to True if the skeletal mesh to be attached to the player uses the same animation data and is based off of the same skeleton as the player character.

• CharacterBasedSkeletalMesh: This map contains the skeletal mesh to be attached to each player character. Here the key is a string(Tag) present on the character skeletal mesh. This is the same used by GenericRetargeter.
• StandaloneSkeletalMesh: This is the general purpose skeletal mesh that can be attached to any character.
• StaticMesh: This is used as a 3D display icon for spawned powerUp component. This will be attached to the player if isSkeletalMesh is set to False.
• SocketName: Leave it empty(None) if UseMasterPose is True else assign the socket name where the static/skeletal mesh should be attached.
• ModifyAnimation: This determines whether or not equipping any powerUp affects the character's movement animation data.
• AnimationData: Similar to AnimationModificationSystem animation data block -
<ul>
• AnimSeq: The animation sequence to use for modifying character's animations.
• Blending: In range 0 to 1, determines the intensity of layering the new animation sequence.
• Slot: The body slot to apply the animation to.
• MinScoreIncrease: The minimum value that can be added to score at any instant.
• MaxScoreIncrease: The maximum value that can be added to score at any instant.
• JumpType: Determines if whether or not the player should jump automatically on equipping any Jump based powerUp or manually on input pressed while not performing any traversal parkour action.
• JumpFreq: Determines whether the powerUp is for single use during its duration or for multiple uses.
• JumpCount: Determines the number of concurrent jumps the player can have.
• JumpZVelocity Min&Max: The upward velocity with which the player jumps is in this range.
• AttractionRadius: Determines the radius of the collectible tracer when magnet powerUp is active.
• CollectibleMultiplier: Determines the number of collectibles collected per collectible instance when counter powerUp is active.
<ul>
• OverlapRadius: The radius of the sphere overlap that detects if player equipped the powerUp.
• PowerUpData: The data asset that this spawner represents.
<ul>
• This is the base blueprint that is spawned infinitely.
• It internally has a child actor component that is assigned a platform(BP_MapBase Class) by the gameMode(BP_RunnerGM) when it is constructed.
• The gameMode(BP_RunnerGM) keeps track of the platform to spawn based on defined rules.
This is a blank copy of BP_Floor for scale reference. It serves no real use in the game or any other system.
<ul>
• Dynamic Obstacles serve as obstacle family containers that spawn a random obstacle from a list of similar obstacles.
• It is useful for spawning obstacles with collectibles and powerUps.
<ul>
• ObstacleData: This takes a data asset of type - PDA_DynamicObsData as input.
<ul>
• ObstacleType: This determines the type of the obstacles in this family.
• CollisionObjectType: This determines the collision property of the obstacles in this family.
• ObstaclesData: This is an array that contains static mesh obstacles with their spawn properties.
<ul>
• SM: Assign the obstacle static mesh here.
• SpawnCollectibles: Whether or not to spawn collectibles with this obstacle.
• ZOffset: Adjust the height of the collectibles from the top of the obstacle.
• ChanceToSpawn: This is the chances of spawning a powerUp on top of this obstacle.
• PowerDataSet: This takes data aset of type - PDA_PowerUpSets as input. These are simply just different groups of powerUps. These groups make it easy for the player to predict upcoming powerUp.
• PowerUpScale: This allows for adjusting the scale of any powerUp that will spawn on any obstacle in this family.
• PowerUpZOffset: This is useful for adjusting the height of the spawned powerUp from the top of the obstacles.
• CollectibleData: See BPC_CollectibleComponent for more details.
• DebugIndex: For any obstacle family DA, you can visualize the properties based on its index.
• DebugObstacle: Toggle this to visualize the properties of obstacle at index DebugIndex in terms of how any obstacle is feeling with collectibles and powerUps spawned.
<ul>
• The properties in BP_DynamicObstacles are global properties. All the obstacles spawned from ObstacleData will have same spawning patterns for powerUps and collectibles.
• Avoid spawning collectibles on thin obstacles.
• Keep the ChancesToSpawnPowerUp low to avoid accumulation of powerUps with the player.
• Blocking obstacles must be of type - WorldDynamic.
<ul>
<li>Blocking obstacles are those which allow climbing, vaulting, mantling, etc; traversals.
• UnderRoll obstacles must be of type - PhysicsBody.
<ul>
<li>UnderRoll obstacles are those which allow sliding, rolling etc; traversals.
<ul>
• Enemies are custom logic defined obstacle blueprints of type BP_BaseEnemyType.
• It is useful for spawning obstacles such as rolling blades, bouncing balls, character enemies and others.
<ul>
• EnemyMeshAsset: Assign the skeletal mesh asset.
• EnemyABP: Assign the enemy animation blueprint. In this project, for character enemies, ABP_CharacterEnemy is used.
• IdleAnimSequences: An array of animation sequences representing idle state of the enemy.
• AttackMontages: An array of attack montages for the enemy to play when enemy collides with the death tracer sphere.
• TauntMontages: An array of taunt montages for the enemy from which a random one is played when player is running in different lane other than the enemy.
• SphereRadius: The radius of the sphere tracer that detects if the player is running in the same/different lane than that of enemy.
• DeathSphereRadius: The radius of the death sphere tracer that kills the player. Attack montage of the enemy is just for visual indication and does not uses traces to hit the player.
• ActorTickIntervalWhenFarAway: The tick interval of the enemy when the player is far away. On colliding with the detection sphere, the tick interval is reset to zero.
<ul>
• These are custom enemy types other than character.
• These use timeline based translation, rotation and scaling to define hit, idle and other states.
• Simply create a child class of BP_AdvObstaclesBase, add your desired components and set up logic similar to the images BP_AOB_BallUpDown and BP_AOB_RollingBlade.
The obstacle system is split into two main components -
<ul>
• BPCC_ObstacleBase: Use for dynamic platforms generation where obstacles can occupy one of many defined positions.
• BPSP_ObstacleBase: Use for static and uniquely designed platforms.
<ul>
• These are the platforms where obstacles are spawned using obstacle families, i.e., BP_DynamicObstacles.
• A random obstacle from any family is spawned in any of the pre-defined spawn indices.
• These are intended for mass generation of two or more different platforms from a single platform by randomly changing the positions of CACs.
<ul>
• DynObsData: An array of elements that configure spawn properties for a dynamic obstacle.
<ul>
• DynObsData: Assign the class reference of the child classes of type BP_DynamicObstacles.

• BanPositionAdjustment: Normally if the SpawnPositions array for any dynamic obstacle contains less than 2 positions, then element '0' is added to the array and the positions are randomized. Banning position adjustment spawns the obstacle only on the indices present in the array.
• Spawn Positions: An array of indices (0-8) where any obstacle from a obstacle family can be spawned randomly.
• EnemySpawnDB: An array for adding enemies/obstacle classes of type BP_BaseEnemyType.
<ul>
• EnemyClass: Assign any enemy of type BP_BaseEnemyType.
• LaneIdx: This controls on which lane enemy is spawned.
• RowLocation: Use this to adjust the position of the enemy on any lane.
• CollectibleDB:An array of structures for configuring properties of more than one or same type of collectibles. See CollectionComponent for more details regarding each element.
• Left & Right EnvironmentClass: Select the environment class asset that you wish to spawn here.
• Offset: Controls the distance of the obstacles from the start position of the map.
• SpawnCollectibles: Controls whether or not the data from CollectibleDB can be used for spawning collectibles.
• DebugPlatform:It is useful for dubugging the object placement on the platform when game is not running.
• DebugArray:It is useful for checking placement of various obstacles on these lane values when game is not running.
<ul>
• SpawnCollectibles doesn’t restricts CACs to spawn collectibles, i.e., BP_DynamicObstacles. Only the data present in CollectibleDB remains unused.
• When the game is running, lane data from GameMode is used.
• Use Offset to push obstacles towards the center of the map.
<ul>
• Used for pre-configured, non-random platforms.
• A fixed obstacle from ObstacleData is spawned at the of the pre-defined spawn index with the given physics behavior.
• These are intended for creation of unique platforms.
<ul>
• Offset: Controls the distance of the obstacles from the start position of the map.
• SpawnPowerUp: Controls whether or not to spawn powerUps on this platform.
• SpawnCollectibles?: Boolean to toggle whether or not collectibles can be spawned on this platform.
• ObstaclesData: An array of structure for storing the obstacle mesh, its physics behavior and spawn point.
• SpawnCollectible:Boolean to determine if collectibles appear above this obstacle.
• ZOffset:Adjusts the vertical height of the obstacle (including the height of obstacle).
• PowerDB: An array of structures for configuring spawn properties of one or more powerUps data sets.
<ul>
• PowerUpDA takes a power up data set asset as input.
• ZOffset defines how high above the ground the powerUp should be spawned.
• SpawnPointIdx is the location at which the powerUp is spawned.
• EnemySpawnDB: An array for adding enemies/obstacle classes of type BP_BaseEnemyType.
<ul>
• EnemyClass: Assign any enemy of type BP_BaseEnemyType.
• LaneIdx: This controls on which lane enemy is spawned.
• RowLocation: Use this to adjust the position of the enemy on any lane.
• CollectibleDB: An array of structures for configuring properties of more than one or same type of collectibles. See CollectionComponent for more details.
• Left & Right EnvironmentClass: Select the environment class(EnvironmentCreationTool) asset that you wish to spawn here.
• DebugPlatform:It is useful for dubugging the object placement on the platform when game is not running.
• DebugArray:It is useful for checking placement of various obstacles on these lane values when game is not running.
<ul>
• Remember to turn off DebugPlatform toggle before finalizing the platform.
• Ensure static meshes have their origin at the bottom-center and collision set to BlockAllDynamic for Blocking Obstacles and PhysicsBody for UnderRolls.
• Use Offset to push the obstacles towards the center of the map.
<ul>
• Platforms can be grouped into Zones (e.g., City, Forest).
• You can set them to cycle Sequentially or Randomly using Data Assets (PDA).
• The management of current zone platforms and when to switch to new zones also occurs in the Game Mode.
Configuration:
<ul>
• Create Zone Data Assets (DAs) from DA_PDA_FD inside Components > PlatformSystem > PDA > ZonePDA by duplicating existing ones and clearing them.
• Now add your platform obstacle sets of type BP_MapBase.
• Add your newly created platform Zone Data Assets to SpawnZonePDA.
• Sequential Mode: If SpawnSequentially is true, the platforms inside any zone will cycle in a fixed order.
• Random Mode:Define MinSpawnedPlatforms and MaxSpawnedPlatforms to randomize how long a zone lasts before switching.
BP_Floor uses the interface function call GetNextFloorClassToSpawn to find the next suitable platform to spawn.

content.value:
1. File -> New Level (Basic).
2. Add BP_PlatformManager and PlayerStart at (0,0,0).
3. Set GameMode to BP_RunnerGM.
4. Press Play.

Q: Does this project use a custom motion matching system?
A: No. This project uses the default motion matching setup and animations from the GameAnimationSampleProject (GASP). No custom motion matching setup was created specifically for this template.

Q: Is game data saved?
A: Yes. Unlike the basic game project, this template uses a SaveGame class (SG_Runner). It automatically saves High Scores, Total Coins, Last Selected Character, and Customization Data.

Q: What plugins are required?
A: You must enable AnimationWarping, MotionWarping, AnimationLocomotionLibrary, PoseSearch, Chooser, RigLogic, LiveLink, and LiveLinkControlRig.

Q: How do I add a new character?
A: You must create a child class of CBP_SandboxCharacter to preserve the running logic. Then, create a Character Data Asset and add it to the DA_PDA_CSD list.

Q: Can I create a straight runner without lanes?
A: Yes. The project includes a GameMode variant called 'Vector' specifically for straight endless runners, alongside the standard 3-Lane 'Runner' mode.

Q: How are platforms managed?
A: The BP_RunnerGM manages the loop. It spawns new platforms when the player overlaps a trigger and deletes old platforms after a set time to maintain performance.

Q: Why do my custom animations look wrong?
A: The default GASP setup is generic. For best results, you need to add specific animations to the chooser or use the CharacterAnimationModification system to layer changes over the base motion matching set.

value: Q: Collectibles are not spawned in the viewport even when SpawnCollectibles is true in dynamic obstacles?
A: Even if SpawnCollectibles (in PDA_DynamicObsData) is set to true, it may happen that collectibles are not spawning with the obstacle in the viewport of BP_DynamicObstacles -
<ul>
• Set DebugIndex to that obstacle's index from ObstacleData.
• Set DebugObstacle to True.
• Play the game.

• In my testing, collectibles were not visible in the viewport, but were spawning correctly during gameplay. In my opinion, this is most likely to do with how world transforms and relative transforms work and I might be using the wrong ones in the wrong places.
